\bib{1991/adleman} \yr 1991 \by Leonard M. Adleman \paper Factoring numbers using singular integers \inbook \cite{1991/awerbuch} \pages 64--71 \endref

[BibTeX .bib file] Introduces the quadratic-characters idea for the number-field sieve.

Some wild speculation on NFS performance in practice: ``Where is the crossover? A naive approach to this question is to ignore the o(1)'s ... 123 decimal digits. However, this may be far too optimistic because it appears that the o(1)'s actually favor the old algorithms. ... It seems possible that the new algorithms may begin to overtake the old ones only on numbers of about 330 decimal digits or so [because at that point QS needs smoothness of numbers] between 165 and 200 decimal digits [while NFS needs smoothness of numbers] of about 188 decimal digits.'' One of the reasons that these figures are bogus is that the 188-digit numbers are chosen to factor into at least two pieces.

\bib{1993/adleman} \yr 1993 \mr 94e:11140 \by Leonard M. Adleman \by Jonathan DeMarrais \paper A subexponential algorithm for discrete logarithms over all finite fields \jour Mathematics of Computation \issn 0025--5718 \vol 61 \pages 1--15 \seeolder \cite{1994/adleman-subexp} \endref

[BibTeX .bib file]

\bib{1994/adleman-subexp} \yr 1994 \mr 95d:94013 \by Leonard M. Adleman \by Jonathan DeMarrais \paper A subexponential algorithm for discrete logarithms over all finite fields \inbook \cite{1994/stinson-book} \pages 147--158 \seenewer \cite{1993/adleman} \endref

[BibTeX .bib file] Presents a discrete-logarithm algorithm for all finite fields, and conjectures that the algorithm takes subexponential time. For finite fields of size p^n with p larger than n, the algorithm writes the field as R/p where R is the ring of integers of a subfield of a fairly small cyclotomic field; the algorithm then works with smooth elements of R. For finite fields of size p^n with p smaller than n, the algorithm works with function fields instead of number fields. Discussion at the end:

It is possible to improve the running time in several ways. Sparse matrix methods can be used to find some dependencies[Wi]. A better bound on q in Algorithm I can be argued heuristically. Smoothness of norms can be tested using the `elliptic curve methods' [Le]. The integer factoring done in various parts can probably be avoided if necessary or `L[1/3]' methods can be used (e.g. [AH, LLMP]). The use of Algorithm II can perhaps be avoided altogether by adopting [sic] Algorithm I to a more general setting. Alternatively the `L[1/3,c]' method of Coppersmith [Co] might be adapted for the case n >= p.

[BibTeX .bib file] Section 1 describes the problems of primality testing, factoring, computing modular roots, and deciding modular powers. Section 2 describes the discrete logarithm problem and the Diffie-Hellman problem, for unit groups and more general groups. Section 3 explains how subexponential times arise from smoothness, surveys factorization algorithms, and surveys discrete-log algorithms. Section 4 discusses ways to pin down the o(1) in run times more precisely.

[BibTeX .bib file] [scanned version] Translated in Soviet Mathematics Doklady 16 (1976) 1005--1008; scan is of translation. Computes reciprocals and roots using Newton's method and fast multiplication. Fails to give credit to Cook, who had published the same method a decade earlier, and whose results were popularized by Knuth in 1969. The last sentence of this paper claims without justification that ``it is possible to adapt the fast iteration method to ... elementary transcendental functions''; in fact, computing exp involves more subtle techniques than Newton's method.

[BibTeX .bib file] Introduction:

At the 1981 IEEE Symposium on Information Theory, T. Herlestam and R. Johannesson presented a heurestic [sic] method for computing logarithms over GF(2^p). They reported computing logarithms over GF(2^{31}) with surprisingly few iterations and claimed that the running time of their algorithm was polynomial in p.

The claim is absurd. This paper, which can be safely forgotten, presents the results of some uninformative calculations related to the Herlestam-Johannesson algorithm.

\bib{1994/buchmann} \yr 1994 \mr 95e:11132 \by Johannes A. Buchmann \by J. Loho \by Joerg Zayer \paper An implementation of the general number field sieve (extended abstract) \inbook \cite{1994/stinson-book} \pages 159--165 \endref

[BibTeX .bib file] I started the first implementation of the general number field sieve in 1991.11, finished it in 1991.12, and wrote several new implementations over the next few months. I wrote the first record-setting implementation in summer 1992, working with Arjen Lenstra. In 1992.07, we used this implementation to factor a 147-digit special number (in about ten Maspar CPU days; as I recall, this meant about 3 10^15 cycles), setting the single-computer factorization record. We also used it to factor a 66-digit general number (in about 1% as much time, without any tuning). In 1992.10, we used it to factor a 158-digit special number, setting the overall factorization record.

Zayer and Loho, students of Buchmann, started another implementation in 1992.03 and finished the first version in 1993.01. They used it to factor a 134-digit special number (in about 3.5 10^15 cycles on an unspecified computer) and a 49-digit general number (in about 2% as much time).

The authors were aware of my previous work when they started theirs. They were aware of my previous 158-digit NFS factorization before they completed any NFS factorizations. They were aware of my previously published paper when they wrote this paper. Yet, incredibly, the authors of this paper failed to even mention my work.
